ygData.subject: Re: A new approach to build structure with CPPNs
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Peter, I ve also started playing around with CPPNs whose output change over time as well.  This sounds like a very interesting idea and I ll be interested

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=274910130; y=GScM804yXzVO6OCXJ-n0c2Dg7PMcZ5DjxkAU_13zSBCxsRc8

Hi Peter,

I've also started playing around with CPPNs whose output change =
over
time as well.  This sounds like a very interesting idea and I'll be
in=
terested to see the results.  In particular it answers the question
I kept =
running into: "How can a CPPN create a structure of arbitrary
size?"  I do =
have a few questions though.

-When new cells are created, how are the assi=
gned coordinates?  Do you
keep things between -1 and 1 or do you let them g=
row to any x,y?  I
ask because I always keep my substrates between -1 and 1=
 because the
functions I use only have "interesting" behavior in those boun=
ds. 
If you do keep them between -1 and 1 though, then it seems like you
wo=
uld have to keep shifting the cells around and it basically amounts
to incr=
easing the resolution of the substrate.

-Do you get a sense that there is =
a benefit to building things this
way?  I have a feeling that there are cer=
tain patterns that are easier
to encode in a developmental process, but I h=
ave a hard time actually
thinking of any that a CPPN could not easily encod=
e on its own.  You
mention that it cuts down on the number of crappy phenot=
ypes, but I'd
guess that there are just as many crappy snapshot patterns as=
 there
are developmental ones, and one would hope that fitness evaluation
w=
ould take care of that in either case.

-Do the cells influence each other =
in anyway, other than dividing?

Thanks,
David

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com=
, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Hi all, 
> 
> Well m=
y project is not finished yet, but here is something that I 
> want to shar=
e with the community. It is about using CPPNs to grow 
> physical or basica=
lly any kind of objects over time. 
> 
> The problem involved when using a =
CPPN to describe a material, 
> physical objects is this. There is no const=
raint in the matter that 
> is available to build an object. One CPPN can o=
utput 100000000000 
> parts and another just one. All in the same genome co=
mplexity. 
> Inverted "images" of the CPPN output can lead to infinite buil=
ding of 
> parts. And more, most objects may just be too bizzare, like a pa=
ttern 
> of concentric circles. The search practitioner has to decide and 
=
> develop too hard things. Like the Alife domain, where you should 
> disca=
rd individuals that do not meet the requirements for something 
> that is m=
eanigful. 
> 
> The idea I propose is that the phenotype can be built witho=
ut 
> quieriyng at each possible coordinate. The CPPN does not have to be a=
 
> snapshot, "printing" an image on the phenotype surface. 
> 
> Consider =
a 2D grid where you have one cell (which I call "the seed") 
> at coordinat=
e 0,0. The CPPN is then asked what to do with that cell. 
> Should it divid=
e, or change type/color/whatever? The CPPN is provided 
> with geometric da=
ta, of course, that is the coordinates of the 
> particular cell that is as=
ked and the time step of development time. 
> After that, the CPPN is asked=
 again, but for those 2 cells, if the 
> first one divides. And then for fo=
ur. And eight. etc... 
> 
> In effect, the CPPN instructs a mass of cells o=
ver time (TIME IS RE-
> INTRODUCED!) of how to develop. A cell divides in t=
his way. If it is 
> not completely surounded by other cells, choose random=
ly a place 
> where to put a new cell. The parent cell still retains its po=
sition. 
> The CPPN has the input of the current cell's position and time u=
ntil 
> end of development. The development of the phenotype happens in 
> =
discrete time steps where all the cells are checked at once and then 
> the=
 phenotype is replaced. 
> 
> During development time, objects of cells app=
ear. I can confirm that 
> these objects's shapes are directly related to t=
he functions used in 
> the CPPNs. In fact, when I use sin(x) and sin(y) fo=
r inputs, they are 
> so.. cool! Like flowers and any kind of shapes. 
> 
>=
 Besides, there are no empty holes, and there is no shit like if you'd 
> t=
ry it with the snapshot approach. All objects are just made 
> of "matter".=
 They can be directly moved over a physical simulation or 
> something like=
 this. 
> 
> This in fact brings the CPPN theory more closely to engeneerin=
g 
> applications and stuff. Also in Artificial Life. In fact my project 
>=
 is dedicated to Alife mostly. 
> 
> Peter Chervenski
>
